common.name: Name
common.noSuggestionsEnterToUse: No suggestions. Press Enter to use.

landing.heroDescription: A mobile-first platform that helps homeowners manage renovation projects, collaborate with contractors, and track every detail from start to finish.
landing.feature1Description: Keep track of rooms, tasks, materials, and costs all in one place. Visual floor plans connect everything together.
landing.feature2Description: Share your project with contractors, designers, and family members. Built-in translation keeps everyone on the same page.
landing.feature3Description: Monitor progress, manage purchase requests, and keep your project moving forward with clear task management.
landing.ctaDescription: Join homeowners who are taking control of their renovation projects

auth.signInDescription: Sign in to your Renomate account

tips.title: Renovation Tips & FAQ
tips.subtitle: Answers to common questions about Swedish renovation permits, processes, and regulations
tips.disclaimer: This information is for general guidance only. Rules vary by municipality and may change. Always contact your local building committee (byggnadsnämnden) or relevant authority for binding decisions regarding your specific project.

whenBuildingPermit.title: When do I need a building permit (bygglov)?
whenBuildingPermit.content:
A building permit is required for most external changes to a building: new construction, extensions, changes to facades, new windows or doors that alter the appearance, changing use (e.g. garage to living space), and building new outbuildings over a certain size.

For single-family homes (one- and two-dwelling buildings), some changes are permit-free, such as painting or re-roofing in the same style, building a small attefall house (max 30 m²), or adding a dormer.

Always check with your municipality — rules can vary depending on your local plan (detaljplan).

permitProcess.title: What does the building permit process look like?
permitProcess.content:
1. Prepare drawings (site plan, floor plans, facades, sections)
2. Submit application to your municipality's building committee
3. The committee reviews the application (normally within 10 weeks)
4. Neighbors may be consulted
5. If approved, you receive a building permit decision
6. Before construction starts, you must have a start notification (startbesked)
7. After completion, you need a final clearance (slutbesked) before use

permitCost.title: How much does a building permit cost?
permitCost.content:
Costs vary by municipality and project scope. A typical building permit for a single-family home extension might cost SEK 10,000–40,000. More complex projects or commercial buildings cost more.

The fee covers the municipality's review and administration. There is no national fixed price — contact your municipality for their fee schedule (taxa).

whenNotification.title: When is a building notification (bygganmälan) required?
whenNotification.content:
A building notification is required for work that doesn't need a building permit but still affects the building's construction, such as:

• Installing or significantly changing load-bearing structures
• Installing or changing ventilation systems
• Installing or changing plumbing and sewage
• Installing a fireplace or stove
• Changing the floor plan inside a building
• Demolition work

You must receive a start notification (startbesked) before work begins.

notificationVsPermit.title: Difference between building permit and building notification
notificationVsPermit.content:
Building permit (bygglov): Required for external changes, new buildings, and changes in use. Involves a more thorough review including neighborhood impact.

Building notification (anmälan): Required for internal technical changes that affect the building's structural integrity, safety, or technical systems. The process is simpler and faster.

Some projects require both a permit and a notification.

technicalConsultation.title: What is a technical consultation (tekniskt samråd)?
technicalConsultation.content:
For larger or more complex projects, the building committee may require a technical consultation before issuing a start notification.

At this meeting you discuss construction plans, quality documentation, inspections, and safety. A certified control manager (kontrollansvarig, KA) is usually required for these projects.

rotDeduction.title: What is the ROT deduction?
rotDeduction.content:
ROT (Renovation, Conversion, Extension) is a tax deduction for labor costs on renovation work in your home. You get 30% off the labor cost (not materials), up to SEK 50,000 per person per year.

The deduction is applied directly on the invoice — you only pay 70% of the labor cost. The contractor claims the rest from Skatteverket.

rotRules.title: Who is eligible for ROT deduction?
rotRules.content:
You must:
• Be at least 18 years old
• Own (or co-own) the property
• Live or plan to live in the property
• Have sufficient tax to deduct against
• Use an F-tax registered contractor

ROT applies to houses, apartments (bostadsrätt), and holiday homes you own. It does not apply to rental apartments or new construction.

rotEligible.title: What renovation work qualifies for ROT?
rotEligible.content:
Eligible work includes:
• Painting and wallpapering
• Floor laying
• Bathroom renovation
• Kitchen renovation (labor only)
• Electrical work
• Plumbing work
• Masonry and tiling
• Roof repairs
• Drainage and ground work

Not eligible: new construction, purchases of materials/appliances, cleaning, garden work (that's RUT).

contractTypes.title: What contract should I use with my contractor?
contractTypes.content:
For consumer contracts with contractors, the standard templates are recommended:

• Hantverkarformuläret 17 — For smaller renovation jobs
• ABS 18 — For building a new house with a contractor
• Småhus 22 — For turnkey house construction

These contracts are developed jointly by consumer and industry organizations and provide balanced terms for both parties. Never start work without a written contract.

quotesOffers.title: Fixed price vs. hourly rate — what should I choose?
quotesOffers.content:
Fixed price (fast pris): The contractor commits to a total price. You know the cost upfront. Best for well-defined projects where the scope is clear.

Hourly rate (löpande räkning): You pay for actual time spent. Can be cheaper for small or uncertain jobs, but the final cost is unknown. The contractor must work efficiently and the price must be reasonable.

Tip: Always get at least 2-3 quotes. If a quote seems very low, ask what's included — it may exclude important items.

consumerRights.title: What are my rights if something goes wrong?
consumerRights.content:
Under the Consumer Services Act (konsumenttjänstlagen):

• The work must be done professionally (fackmässigt)
• The contractor must warn you about risks or unexpected issues
• You can claim defects for up to 10 years after completion
• If the work is defective, you can demand correction at no cost
• You can withhold payment proportional to the defect
• In serious cases, you can cancel the contract

Always document defects with photos and notify the contractor in writing.

contractorInsurance.title: Should my contractor have insurance?
contractorInsurance.content:
Yes, always verify that your contractor has:

• Liability insurance (ansvarsförsäkring) — covers damage to your property during work
• F-tax registration — means they handle their own taxes
• Check for any tax debts or issues at Skatteverket

You can verify F-tax status at skatteverket.se. Ask the contractor to show their insurance certificate before work starts.

warrantyRules.title: How long is the warranty on renovation work?
warrantyRules.content:
Under Swedish consumer law, you can claim defects for up to 10 years after the work was completed. However, you should report defects as soon as you discover them (within 'reasonable time').

Many contractors offer a specific warranty period (1-5 years) — this does not limit your legal rights but may make the claims process easier during that period.

Always do a thorough inspection (slutbesiktning) when the work is finished.

homeInsurance.title: Does my home insurance cover renovation damage?
homeInsurance.content:
Home insurance typically covers sudden and unforeseen damage, but usually NOT:
• Damage caused by the contractor's negligence (that's their liability insurance)
• Gradual damage from poor workmanship
• Cost overruns or delays

Check with your insurance company before major renovations. Some insurers want to be notified about large renovation projects. Extended coverage may be available.

condoPermission.title: What renovations can I do in my condo (bostadsrätt)?
condoPermission.content:
As a condo owner, you are responsible for the interior of your apartment. You can generally:
• Paint and wallpaper
• Change flooring
• Replace kitchen cabinets and appliances
• Change interior doors

You need board permission for:
• Changes to load-bearing walls
• Changes to plumbing, drainage, or ventilation
• Changes that affect the building's exterior
• Any work that may affect other apartments

Check your association's statutes (stadgar) for specific rules.

condoWetRooms.title: Renovating bathrooms in a condo — special rules
condoWetRooms.content:
Bathroom renovations in condos require extra care:

• You need board approval in most associations
• Waterproofing (tätskikt) must be done by a certified professional (e.g. GVK or BKR certified)
• The work must follow BBR (Boverkets byggregler) standards
• Your association may require specific contractors or materials
• You are liable for water damage to other apartments caused by faulty renovation

Always use certified professionals and get proper documentation.

condoLiability.title: Who is liable for damage during condo renovation?
condoLiability.content:
You are personally responsible for all work done inside your apartment, even if a contractor performs the work. This means:

• You must ensure the contractor is qualified and insured
• You are liable for damage to common areas or other apartments
• Water damage from a faulty bathroom renovation is your responsibility
• The association can require you to restore things if you've made unauthorized changes

Tip: Get a separate renovation insurance (renoveringsförsäkring) for major projects.
